What is a viral infection?

Viruses are very tiny infectious agents. They’re also made up of pieces of genetic material, which are either RNA or DNA, enclosed in protein coats.

Viruses are parasitic organisms which attack cells in your body and use materials of those cells to regenerate. Such process often damage the host cells.  So the term viral infection, simply mean an ailment caused by a virus.

All viruses aren’t contagious

You’ll have to drop the misconception that all viruses are contagious. Because all viruses are not contagious. However, many of them are, e.g. are HIV, Herpes, common cold and the flu. Other types of viral infections can be spread through insect or rodent bites.

Basic types of viral infections

Hepatic viral infections:

This viral disease is known to cause inflammation of the liver and the prevalent types are Hepatitis A,B and C. You also have to know that other diseases like yellow fever and cytomegalovirus also limit the function of the liver. It’s other less common types are D and E.

Transmission

Spread through contaminated objects, bite of an infected animal or insect, and close contact with infected persons.

Treatments

Presently, there are no specific treatment for people with encephalitis or mild viral meningitis. Doctors advise that patients stay hydrated, get plenty of rest and take the prescribed anti-inflammatory drugs, so as to ease the pain. In some cases, antiviral medication is prescribed.

Prevention

Presently there is a vaccine for polio virus and mumps, which causes encephalitis and meningitis. But still, you need to have practice good hygiene. Avoid close contact with infected persons and protect yourself against insect or dog bites. To reduce the risk of the spread of rabies, vaccinate your pets and avoid wild animals.

  Respiratory viral infections:

This infections are contagious and usually affect the upper and lower parts of your respiratory system.

Symptoms usually detected when infected are:

  • fever
  • body aches
  • runny nose
  • sneezing
  • cough
  • stuffy nose

Examples of respiratory infections are:

  • common cold
  • flu
  • adenovirus infection
  • flu
  • parainfluenza virus infection
  • sever acute respiratory syndrome (SARS)

Transmission

These infections are spread by minute droplets generated via sneezing and coughing. If someone sneezes or coughs near you and you inhale the droplets, you’ll likely develop the infection and also via infected objects.

Treatment

Most times, these infections heal on their own or you can as well get medications over the counter (OTC).

Prevention

Simply practice good hygiene. Be cautious about this. In medical facilities, there are vaccines that’ll help you reduce the risk of getting the seasonal flu.

Exanthematous viral infection

This type of virus cause skin rash, and many of them cause additional symptoms too, e.g., Measles.

Transmission

These infections are spread via respiratory droplets or contact with infected persons.

Treatment

Most times, doctors manage the symptoms or give antiviral drugs to lessen the effects of the infections.

Prevention

Simply vaccinate yourself, and to avoid “chikungunya” protect yourself against mosquitoes.

Neurological viral infections

These are viruses which affect the neural network and the brain. Symptoms include: confusion, fever, seizures, coordination problems, etc. Examples are; rabies, polio, meningitis, encephalitis.

Hemorrhagic viral infection

These are infections that damage your circulatory system. Symptoms include; weakness, high fever, bleeding under the skin, bleeding in the internal organs, bleeding from mouth and ears, and body aches. Examples are; Lassa fever, Ebola, Yellow fever, Dengue fever, etc.

Treatment

Presently, there is no cure. But it’s important you keep your body hydrated, while some people may need intravenous fluids to maintain electrolyte balance. In essence, supportive care to maintain both electrolyte balance and hydration is important.

conclusion

There are many less serious viruses, which come up at certain times and disappear on their own. While some can be quite serious. Unlike their bacterial counterparts, viruses do not respond to antibiotics. Instead popular treatments are managing symptoms, supporting the immune system and drinking lots of water.

And the best type of treatment you can get, is by having good hygiene, being less discriminating and taking care of your environment.
